Dates and lineups are subject to change; check vaccine and mask requirements for individual performers and venues.

headline: 54 Dance Programs, Festivals and More Coming This Fall
text: Compared to the strange, transformative exhilaration of last fall’s return to live performance, this season’s dance calendar feels both more abundant and more introspective. Many presenters are back to their pre-shutdown schedules and are once again able to welcome an array of international performers; many dance artists are only beginning to reckon with the fallout of the pandemic and other global crises, exploring themes of grief and upheaval. (Proof of vaccination may be required at live performances, which remain subject to changes because of Covid-19; check websites for updated information.)

headline: 159 Films, for Every Taste, Coming This Fall
text: Steven Spielberg returns to his childhood, Ryan Coogler returns to Wakanda and James Cameron returns to Pandora in just some of the films coming out this fall, following what was generally perceived as a blah summer for movies. And these listings are just a start. Some titles, like “Causeway,” with Jennifer Lawrence, and the Cannes prizewinner “Close,” hadn’t settled on release dates by press time.

headline: U.K.’s New Leader Lays Out Sweeping Plan to Cap Energy Prices
text: LONDON — Scrambling to spare millions of households the pain of skyrocketing energy bills this winter, Britain’s new prime minister, Liz Truss, announced a sweeping plan on Thursday to freeze gas and electricity rates for two years, at a cost of tens of billions of pounds to the British Treasury.

headline: The body of a British aid worker captured by Russian proxies showed signs of torture, a Ukrainian official says.
text: A British aid worker who died in custody after being captured by pro-Russian forces in Ukraine appears to have suffered “possible unspeakable torture,” according to the Ukrainian government.

headline: ‘True Things’ Review: Escape Routes
text: Harry Wootliff’s “True Things” bottles the lightning of a torrid fling in its closely observed character study of Kate, a bored British social worker who feels stuck. Tom Burke plays a charming bloke, recently released from prison, who comes in for a benefits claim and ends up asking her out. “I will keep that in mind,” Kate (Ruth Wilson) responds, intrigued but trying not to smile.

headline: BlackRock Seeks to Defend Its Reputation Over E.S.G. Fight
text: BlackRock wants to clear the air on “woke” investing.

headline: Michelle Obama’s White House Portrait: Arms and the Woman
text: How does a first lady claim her part in history? How does she sum up her accomplishments in her non-job job?

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Paschitta
text: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. Play previous Chess Replay puzzles here.

headline: ‘CoComelon’ Video Game Is a First for Fast-Growing Moonbug
text: Moonbug Entertainment, a children’s media company that has become a surprise force in toddler television, competing nimbly against incumbents like Disney and Nickelodeon, announced an expansion into video games on Thursday. CoComelon: Play With JJ, aimed at players ages 2 to 4 and their parents, will arrive on Nintendo Switch on Oct. 28 in partnership with Outright Games and cost $40.

headline: The Artist Sculpting a Terra-Cotta Forest
text: I use less and less as I get older, but I make sure what I do use is really great. First thing in the morning, while I’m still in bed, I spray Chantecaille rosewater all over to help myself wake up. Then I shower and use Leonor Greyl Shampooing Reviviscence — on my hair and on my body, too — then Christophe Robin’s Shade Variation Mask in Baby Blonde. I am so devoted to my colorist in New York, Sharon Dorram, so I do all I can to preserve her work. If I do a blowout at home, I’ll use Dyson’s Airwrap. After the shower, I apply our Bio Lifting Serum and Rose de Mai Cream. In the summer I follow that with our Anti-Aging Face Tint in sheer bronze, and in the winter I’ll use our Sheer Glow Rose Face Tint and Future Skin foundation in one of four tones depending on how much sun I’ve had. The tints give you a little bit of a highlight and make your skin look delicious. I use a number of eye products, including our Nano Gold Energizing Eye Serum and the Eye Cream from the same range. When it comes to makeup, one thing I have to have is a very good eye pencil — I’m partial to our Luster Glide in Earth or Olive Brocade, which is green with a little blue. And I have a myriad of lipsticks but, right now, I’m using a lip tint we launched this summer. It looks so natural and is really moisturizing. If I have been outside all day, I will sleep in our Gold Recovery Mask and, the next day, it’s like my skin has no memory of being in the sun. And if I’m going to be on television, I’ll do our Bio Lifting Mask to help with wrinkles. I’m a gardener and don’t get manicures, but my mother got me started using Dior’s Creme Abricot on my nails — that and Aesop’s Resurrection Aromatique Hand Balm. I get pedicures at Spa 27 in East Hampton and I do acupuncture in Amagansett with Sandra Foster. I love Arnican, too. If you have a bruise just use that little orange tube. Le Wild is my signature scent — it’s based on a wild gardenia found in a forest in Brazil and is really fresh but has a lot of energy. I feel that it represents my life in that all that I love is wild. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Can Architecture Build Values, Too?
text: It’s been a harrowing ride for projects coming to fruition this fall, planned in what now seems a faraway time before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the ricocheting effects of Covid-19, and disasters fueled by climate change. Yet the best architecture can transform our ways of thinking, our work, our connections to local community. The designs presented here seek to transcend the moment’s crises.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: This week’s properties are in Dumbo, Lenox Hill and Turtle Bay.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
text: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in the New York Region

headline: How California Officials Are Trying to Keep the Lights On
text: The huge heat dome that has engulfed California for more than a week appears to be weakening, although meteorologists say triple-digit temperatures will remain with us for a couple more days. On Wednesday, residents were asked yet again to conserve power between 4 p.m. and 9 p.m., when the grid tends to get strained. Don’t be surprised if today brings yet another so-called flex alert.

headline: Jerome Powell speaks on monetary policy.
text: The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome H. Powell, spoke at conference hosted by the Cato Institute, a libertarian think tank.

headline: U.S. Open Semifinals: The 4 Women Left
text: Caroline Garcia, Ons Jabeur, Aryna Sabalenka and Iga Swiatek have a title in their sights.

headline: Saudi-Tied Tournament Causes Push to Void Trump’s N.Y.C. Golf Contract
text: It sounded like the type of event that Mayor Eric Adams would want to bring to New York City to boost the economy: an elite international golf tournament that would draw visitors and their wallets.

headline: Bannon Pleads Not Guilty to New York Charges in Wall Case
text: Stephen K. Bannon, the self-professed populist adviser to former President Donald J. Trump, was accused by Manhattan prosecutors on Thursday of defrauding Americans who wanted to contribute to construction of a southern border wall, resurrecting a threat that Mr. Bannon seemed to have escaped with a 2021 presidential pardon.

headline: Jerome Powell signals interest rates will remain high to fight inflation.
text: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, signaled on Thursday that the central bank will continue raising interest rates to convince the American public that it is serious about bringing soaring price growth back to normal levels, further cementing market expectations of another aggressive rate increase this month.

headline: Philippines Rebuffs International Court Over Duterte’s War on Drugs
text: MANILA — The Philippine government on Thursday officially rejected a request by the chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court to resume an investigation into former President Rodrigo Duterte’s war on drugs, which left thousands of people dead.

headline: Investors Sue Treasury Department for Blacklisting Crypto Platform
text: A group of cryptocurrency investors sued the Treasury Department on Thursday to block government sanctions that bar Americans from Tornado Cash, a popular crypto platform that criminals have used to launder virtual currencies.

headline: Here are the takeaways from the E.C.B.’s big move.
text: The European Central Bank raised its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a point on Thursday, and said that it expected to continue raising them in the future. The central bank also published a new set of economic forecasts.

headline: The Harrowing Migration Story of One 9-Year-Old Child
text: Javier Zamora was born in El Salvador in 1990 during the country’s civil war. His father fled to the United States first, a year after Zamora was born, and his mother followed when he was 5. For the next four years, he lived with his grandparents; then it was his turn to go north. Zamora’s memoir, “Solito,” is a chronicle of that journey, which Zamora made by himself at the age of 9, from a tiny village in El Salvador to Arizona — thousands of miles in all.

headline: ‘The Woman King’ and Intimate Moments Amid Epic Action
text: From her debut feature, the rom-com classic “Love and Basketball,” to her most recent action hit, “The Old Guard,” Gina Prince-Bythewood is known for films with rich character introspection amid outward chaos. That touch is evident again this fall even as she widens her cinematic playing field with the fact-based battle epic “The Woman King.”

headline: ‘Barbarian’ Review: This Rental Is Hell
text: “Barbarian,” a gleefully twisty horror movie by the writer-director Zach Cregger, is both a product of modern times and something of a throwback.

headline: Ask Wirecutter: Dollar Store Duds?
text: How do I get my mom to stop buying junk?

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Serena Williams’s Record and Legacy
text: Serena Williams announced she is retiring from professional tennis after a 27-year career. During this time, she broke down barriers for Black tennis players and female athletes. This graph compares the ages of Williams and her opponents for all of her championship tennis matches. She went pro in 1995 at the age of 14 and she announced on Aug. 9, 2022, that she will retire this year (at the age of 40).

headline: EY, the accounting and consulting firm, will split into two businesses.
text: EY, one of the world’s biggest auditing and consulting firms, is moving forward with a plan to split up its two main business practices.

headline: David Shor, a Data Guru for Democrats, Throws One Last Bash
text: At 7 p.m. on Saturday, the political consultant David Shor was setting up his fifth-floor apartment in Lower Manhattan for one last blowout party before the start of election season, when he expects to work between 65 and 70 hours a week crunching numbers on behalf of Democratic candidates across the country.

headline: Trump’s Post-Election Fund-Raising Comes Under Scrutiny by Justice Dept.
text: A federal grand jury in Washington is examining the formation of — and spending by — a fund-raising operation created by Donald J. Trump after his loss in the 2020 election as he was soliciting millions of dollars by baselessly asserting that the results had been marred by widespread voting fraud.

headline: What We're Reading This Fall
text: Good news, book lovers: This is a great season to be a reader. Let us help you find your next book.

headline: Boy, 15, Fatally Shot in Downtown Brooklyn Park, Police Say
text: A 15-year-old boy was shot and killed in McLaughlin Park, in Downtown Brooklyn, on Wednesday afternoon after two people approached him and started a verbal dispute that turned physical, the police said.

headline: Live by the Trump, Die by the Trump
text: Democrats were doomed. We prediction-mad pundits felt predictable certainty about that. The recent history of midterm elections augured disaster for the party in power. Inflation would make the damage that much worse.

headline: Does Anyone Drink Hot Coffee Anymore?
text: Hannah Maute’s obsession with iced lattes, iced coffees and cold brews began during her freshman year at Temple University, where she was surrounded by students who “looked cool” bouncing from class to class with a cup in hand. Now, not a day goes by when she isn’t sipping one herself.

headline: Meet Four Theater Artists to Watch This Fall
text: The actor Gregg Mozgala has dark hair swooped back from his forehead and watchful, heavy-lidded eyes. His upper body is muscular, his right arm etched with two elaborate tattoos, one showing a rooster mid crow. He credits his family’s focus on athletics for the vigor of his performances.

headline: 445 Prompts for Narrative and Personal Writing
text: We’ve been posting fresh writing prompts every school day for over a decade now, and every so often we create a themed collection like this one to help you find what you need all in one place.

headline: Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine Looks Like a ‘Failure,’ C.I.A. Director Says
text: Six months into “a very tough slog of a war,” Ukraine has begun to mount a counteroffensive and Russia’s invasion can only be seen as a failure, the director of the C.I.A., William J. Burns, said Thursday.

headline: Independent 20th Century’s Artists in a Cozy New Fair Spinoff
text: The Independent Art Fair, already curated and intimate, has gotten even cozier. In its brand-new spinoff, Independent 20th Century — some 32 galleries showing work by 20th-century artists both famous and unfamiliar — occupies a single floor of the Battery Maritime Building on South Street. (I found the building a little claustrophobic when it hosted the regular Independent last year, but for this it works perfectly.)

headline: New York City Center Taps Veteran Arts Administrator as Its Next Leader
text: New York City Center, a nonprofit known for its starry short-run musical revivals as well as its contemporary dance programming, is naming a New Jersey arts administrator as its new leader.

headline: Review: A Singer’s Immense Sound Engulfs a Recital Room
text: Some singers thrive in a recital room. A small space invites extremities of intimate expression; audiences can become the confidants of a lovelorn raconteur. Other voices, though, are better fit for an opera house — voluminous to the point of superhuman strength, thrilling for their athleticism as much their artistry.

headline: F.D.A. OKs Daxxify, an Anti-Wrinkle Drug and Botox Competitor
text: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a new drug that reduced the appearance of facial wrinkles for about six months, spurring competition in a market that for decades has been dominated by Botox.

headline: The U.S. will send an additional $675 million in military supplies to Ukraine, Austin says.
text: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany — Emphasizing that the United States was prepared to support Ukraine “for the long haul,” Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said Thursday that Washington will send an additional $675 million in military supplies to Ukraine, including air-launched missiles designed to destroy enemy radars.

headline: A Goodbye to Readers and a Reflection
text: I’ve had the opportunity to write the On Tech newsletter for the past two and a half years, and now that time has come to an end. This is my last edition.

headline: As Pennsylvania Senate Race Tightens, Oz Sharpens Attacks on Fetterman
text: SPRINGFIELD, Pa. — Dr. Mehmet Oz, trailing in the polls and still contending with an image as an out-of-touch, carpetbagging elitist, is seeking to reboot his Senate campaign in Pennsylvania in the final sprint to November.

headline: Mercedes and Rivian Plan to Make Vans Together in Europe
text: Mercedes-Benz and Rivian said Thursday that they would team up to build electric vans in Europe, a rare example of cooperation between a traditional carmaker and a new challenger.

headline: Bernard Shaw, CNN’s Lead Anchor for 20 Years, Dies at 82
text: Bernard Shaw, CNN’s lead prime-time anchor for 20 years, who was also known for his steely coverage from Tiananmen Square in Beijing during the Chinese government’s crackdown on protesters in 1989 and from Baghdad at the start of the Persian Gulf war two years later, died on Wednesday. He was 82.

headline: When There’s Nothing in the Fridge
text: I got home late on Monday from a friend’s wedding in New Hampshire, dropped my bags and went straight to the fridge.

headline: Balmoral Castle has a long history as a royal retreat in the Scottish Highlands.
text: Queen Victoria fell so in love in June 1852 with a sweeping estate in the Scottish Highlands that she later called it “this dear paradise,” and her husband, Prince Albert, bought it for her.

headline: Schaller & Weber Adds a Cocktail Bar to Its Upper East Side Realm
text: The butcher shop Schaller & Weber, a vestige of the German American culture that once flourished in the Yorkville section of the Upper East Side, plans to add a little Austrian flavor to its stretch of Second Avenue.

text: The indictment charging Stephen K. Bannon.

headline: NASA Could Retry Moon Rocket Launch in Late September
text: After replacing leaky seals that halted a launch attempt of its new moon rocket last week, NASA said on Thursday that it hoped to try again later this month.

headline: Macron Aims for a National Dialogue at a Meeting, but Faces No-Shows
text: PARIS — Seemingly humbled by the fractures in French society exposed during the election that ultimately led to his second term as France’s president, Emmanuel Macron promised to rule in a new way — fewer dictates from above and more collaborating.

headline: Mourn the Queen, Not Her Empire
text: “The end of an era” will become a refrain as commentators assess the record-setting reign of Queen Elizabeth II. Like all monarchs, she was both an individual and an institution. She had a different birthday for each role — the actual anniversary of her birth in April and an official one in June — and, though she retained her personal name as monarch, held different titles depending on where in her domains she stood. She was as devoid of opinions and emotions in public as her ubiquitous handbags were said to be of everyday items like a wallet, keys and phone. Of her inner life we learned little beyond her love of horses and dogs — which gave Helen Mirren, Olivia Colman and Claire Foy rapt audiences for the insights they enacted.

headline: The Legacy of Elizabeth II: The Media Queen
text: Queen Elizabeth II, the longest-reigning monarch in British history, died at the age of 96, leaving behind a legacy that blended the ancient and the modern with the help of mass media.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II: A Life in Photos
text: LONDON — Born in 1926, eight years after the end of World War I, Elizabeth took her first steps in a world we recognize only from sepia photographs, in a country yet to see its first public TV broadcast and one that was in some respects more like the 19th century than the 21st.

headline: An Inscrutable Monarch, Endlessly Scrutinized Onstage and Onscreen
text: She was the most opaque of celebrities, a silent film star somehow thriving in a TikTok world. If no one except her closest friends and family knew what Queen Elizabeth was really like, that’s exactly how she wanted it.

headline: Authorities Say D.N.A. Links Las Vegas Official to Killing of Reporter
text: LAS VEGAS — Authorities investigating the killing of a veteran Las Vegas journalist, Jeff German, said Thursday that they found D.N.A. at the crime scene that matched a public official who had been the subject of Mr. German’s recent reporting.

headline: Why Economic Populism Remains the Winning Ticket
text: For those who see the Democratic Party in turmoil, poised to lose its razor-thin congressional majority in November, and then the White House in 2024, Michael Tomasky has a message for you: Calm down.

headline: Queen Elizabeth Embodied the Myth of the Good Monarch
text: To function in an otherwise normal democracy, a hereditary monarchy requires that the citizenry accept a bit of fiction — namely that one family, standing above politics, can represent the nation and its values.

headline: What Makes Your Brain Different From a Neanderthal’s?
text: Scientists have discovered a glitch in our DNA that may have helped set the minds of our ancestors apart from those of Neanderthals and other extinct relatives.

headline: Failure to Slow Warming Will Set Off Climate ‘Tipping Points,’ Scientists Say
text: Failure to limit global warming to the targets set by international accords will most likely set off several climate “tipping points,” a team of scientists said on Thursday, with irreversible effects including the collapse of the Greenland and West Antarctic ice sheets, abrupt thawing of Arctic permafrost and the death of coral reefs.

headline: A Storied New York Gallery Comes Home
text: Here’s a story that serves as a worthy metaphor for the current state of the art world: In 2018, the construction of an imposing mixed-use real estate development on West 21st Street in New York City damaged its neighbor, Paula Cooper Gallery, a beloved exhibition space that was then forced to close and relocate to a different building a few blocks north. Shortly after, the development stalled, leaving behind a shuttered gallery and a vacant lot.

headline: Lillias White Finds Her Goddess for ‘Hadestown’
text: “I can’t do anything today!” Lillias White said as she emerged, somewhat flustered, from the elevator outside the Tricorne costume shop on the sixth floor of a Midtown Manhattan office building on a recent Tuesday morning. Her face was hidden behind white sunglasses and a navy and green star-patterned mask.

headline: ‘Dos Estaciones’ Review: A Tequila Factory’s Story, Sip by Sip
text: There is a startling moment in the soulful Mexican drama “Dos Estaciones” when it shifts from the protagonist to a secondary character. Movies often take detours, yet when they pop into a supporting player’s life or nose around the story’s periphery, it’s usually to expand on the main event. Here, though, the diversion is so imbued by the secondary character’s being, so organic and leisurely, that it feels like the beginning of another movie entirely.

headline: Planning for the End of Elizabeth’s Reign Began at the Beginning
text: LONDON — The death of Queen Elizabeth II sets in motion a meticulously choreographed and coordinated procedure for which the palace, the government, the news media, the local authorities and the queen herself had long planned.

headline: Two Critics, 13 Favorite Booths at The Armory Show
text: The fall art season has arrived, with its manic harvest of exhibitions, and also The Armory Show, the major art fair in New York City that shifted its schedule and venue last year, moving to this early-September date and the Javits Center. With some 240+ galleries showing, and solid delegations from every continent, the fair is abundant and properly international again after a slimmed-down 2021 edition constrained by Covid-19 travel restrictions and hesitancy. Those are gone now — though the pandemic continues — and the scene is buzzing.

headline: 3 Browsers’ Delights Among the Art Fairs in NYC
text: This weekend, there is no shortage of art fairs. If you can’t make it to the Independent or the mammoth Armory Show — or if smaller fairs with nascent artists are more your style — there are satellite art fairs taking place across the city. Here’s a quick guide to our top three.

headline: Long an Uneasy Prince, King Charles III Takes On a Role He Was Born To
text: LONDON — Never, perhaps, has an heir been more ready for the crown.

headline: What it was like to portray the queen onscreen.

headline: Vice journalists raise concerns about potential deal with Saudi-backed firm.

headline: Conditions at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Are ‘Unsustainable,’ U.N. Watchdog Warns
text: KYIV, Ukraine — The head of the United Nations nuclear energy watchdog on Friday stepped up his calls for the creation of a safe zone around the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in Ukraine after renewed shelling caused a widespread blackout in the town where the plant’s workers live.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
text: Almost 30 years ago, when I was first coming up in this business, Randall Kenan was a young writer to watch: the author of an acclaimed novel, “A Visitation of Spirits,” and a story collection, “Let the Dead Bury Their Dead,” who combined folklore and magical realism and a rollicking biblical lyricism to bring his native rural North Carolina to life. I knew Kenan briefly in his New York years, when he taught a writing workshop at my school, and he seemed poised to make it as big as anyone ever does in the literary realm. But fame is fickle, and the moment passed, and so rather than a household name Kenan became that noble thing, the “writers’ writer,” continuing to produce excellent and award-nominated work for decade after decade until he died, too young, in 2020.

headline: Kay, a Post-Tropical Cyclone, Moves Up Baja California’s Western Coast
text: A storm that formed off the Pacific shores of Mexico moved up the coast of the Baja California peninsula and brought heavy winds and rain into California, which has already been coping with extreme heat, wildfires and drought.

headline: The Disappearing World of Wolfgang Tillmans
text: It doesn’t seem like a titillating photograph: an orderly queue of Germans, waiting to enter a nondescript industrial site. It is dark. Just a single light illuminates the door. What does it look like? Like a color remake of Depression-era imagery: the factory entrance, the bread line.

headline: Yellen Embarks on Economic Victory Tour as Midterm Elections Approach
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — Emerging from months of inflation and recession fears, the Biden administration is pivoting to recast its stewardship of the U.S. economy as a singular achievement. In their pitch to voters, two months before midterm elections determine whether Democrats will maintain full control of Washington, Biden officials are pointing to a postpandemic resurgence of factories and “forgotten” cities.

headline: Britain’s national anthem will swap ‘king’ for ‘queen’ as Charles takes the throne.
text: Numerous small changes to British daily life are expected in the coming weeks to welcome the new monarch — King Charles III, who ascended to the throne after the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, on Thursday.

headline: President Biden remembers a monarch who ‘defined an era.’

text: Queen Elizabeth II’s coffin began its journey on Sunday, traveling from Balmoral Castle to Edinburgh. The queen, who died on Thursday, Sept. 8, lay in rest in Edinburgh until Tuesday afternoon. Her coffin was flown to London on Tuesday evening to lie in state ahead of her funeral on Monday at Westminster Abbey.

Trump’s Florida home, arguing that her ruling was hindering the government’s effort to determine whether national security had been compromised.

headline: The U.S. announces sanctions on Iranian companies involved in Russia drone sales.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: Queen Elizabeth II Dies at 96

headline: Michigan Voters Will Decide Abortion Rights Question, Court Says

text: WASHINGTON — They danced with her, rode horses together and went for a boat ride or a picnic. They took her to church or a baseball game. They hosted her or were hosted by her for gala dinners and receptions. Most of all, they basked in her global prestige and historical majesty.

headline: The Queen’s Death Comes at a Moment of Great Uncertainty for Britain
text: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II, whose seven-decade reign made her the only sovereign that most Britons had ever known, died on Thursday at her summer estate in Scotland, thrusting a bereaved country into a momentous transition at a time of political and economic upheaval.

headline: In Memphis, Renewed Attention on Violence After Shooting Rampage

Two men dressed in orange and black, wearing white hats emblazoned with the words “Oklahoma State,” cheered her on.

headline: In a Divided Britain, Near Unity in Admiration of the Queen
text: LONDON — On Thursday evening, hours after the death of Queen Elizabeth was announced, the British capital was just starting to process its collective loss.

headline: The Tennis Umpire With the Velvet Voice Makes His Call
text: Trailing 5-4 in the second set of her first-round match in this year’s U.S. Open, Venus Williams hit a forehand winner down the line to bring the game to 40-40. The chair umpire, Kader Nouni, let out a booming “deuce” that reverberated throughout Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Teddy Bears and Racial Justice: How St. Louis Became a Laboratory for Social Work
text: ST. LOUIS — It’s called the Delmar Divide, named for the once-grand boulevard that bisects this city into enclaves that have long been more starkly segregated than almost anywhere else in America.

headline: The Immortal Awfulness of Open Plan Workplaces
text: Oscar Wilde is said to have quipped that “God, in creating man, somewhat overestimated his ability.” Our species is capable of folly on a grand scale. Exhibit No. 4,000 in this litany of woe is the continued existence of open plan workplaces.

headline: ‘End of the Road’ Review: Thrill Ride
text: A family of four traverses an obstacle course of Wild West crime escapades in the charming caper “End of the Road.” Queen Latifah and Chris Bridges anchor the antics as Brenda, a mother of two teenagers, and Reggie, Brenda’s layabout younger brother. Their sibling alliance forms the heart of the movie, and the pair toggle credibly between a combative dynamic and a considerate one.

headline: Wartime Economics Comes to Europe
text: The West isn’t exactly at war with Russia. However, it isn’t exactly not at war, either. Western weapons have helped Ukraine to stall Russia’s invasion and even to counterattack, while Western economic sanctions have clearly created serious problems for Russian industry.

headline: Trump Media Merger Gives Itself Another Month to Scramble for Shareholder Votes

headline: Meghan and Harry’s children could now inherit royal titles.

text: Frances Tiafoe has everything needed to be a difference maker in tennis.

headline: When You Can’t Stand the Sound of Chewing (or Crunching, or Sniffling)
text: I’m a fairly calm person, but one thing that launches me into a fit of rage is the sound of my husband chewing. I can’t say whether his chewing differs in a demonstrable way from other people’s chewing, other than the fact that I’m subjected to it on a daily basis. But I do know that his chewing sounds are the only ones that make me want to pick up my chair and hurl it across the room.

headline: Breast Implants May Be Linked to Additional Cancers, F.D.A. Warns
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday warned women who have breast implants or are considering getting them that certain cancers may develop in scar tissue forming around the implants.

headline: Intense California Wildfire Begins Creating Its Own Weather
text: The Mosquito fire is prompting new evacuations on Thursday and alarming firefighters and meteorologists with its rapid spread and huge plume of smoke as it burns its way through dry, hilly terrain northeast of Sacramento.

headline: Ons Jabeur Will Play Iga Swiatek for the U.S. Open Women’s Singles Title
text: There will be a new U.S. Open women’s singles champion this year, and Ons Jabeur and Iga Swiatek remained in contention in very different ways on Thursday night in Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: Can you get reinfected with monkeypox?
text: The United States has reported more monkeypox cases than any other country in the world. As people recover from their infections, they’ll naturally want to avoid a repeat infection and repeat episodes of the pain and fear associated with the disease.

headline: ‘About Fate’ Review: Love the One You’re With?
text: A few coincidences can have their charms, but the romantic comedy “About Fate,” directed by Marius Vaysberg and written by Tiffany Paulsen (“Holidate”), creaks under the weight of a pile of improbabilities.

headline: First Pass Friday: Work the Crossings, Luke
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Welcome back to First Pass Friday, the occasional feature that shows readers how I worked my way through the dreaded, second-hardest puzzle of the week (the hardest is on Saturday). Please go ahead and feel superior to me before the solving begins. There will be no intermission in today’s column.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
text: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is from a 2019 book by Emily Nussbaum, a Pulitzer Prize-winning television critic for The New Yorker, called “I Like to Watch: Arguing My Way Through the TV Revolution.” I’m part of the decreasing population of people who grew up before streaming and e-books, which means that I still mentally schedule viewings of shows that are available 24/7, and I still reflexively consider reading to be a worthwhile effort and television to be indulgent entertainment. Ms. Nussbaum thinks we should evolve beyond that snobbery; I agree, and it seems inevitable anyway.

headline: Connecticut Sun Complete Comeback to Reach W.N.B.A. Finals
text: The Chicago Sky looked like they were on their way to their second straight appearance in the W.N.B.A. finals. They led Connecticut by 9 points with less than five minutes to go in the decisive Game 5, and had held the Sun to just 14 points since halftime. Sky guard Kahleah Copper was dominating, forcing turnovers, flexing her muscles and clapping her hands en route to a game-high 22 points.

headline: Developing a Harmony at Different Stages in Life
text: As is often the case in New York, housing crises can lead to life-altering changes in direction. For Matei Varga, 41, being kicked out of an apartment led to an unexpected romance with Melissa Gibbs, 84.

headline: Two Journalists Who Cover Hate Find Love
text: Tess Alexandra MacVicar Owen and Andrew Blaise Campbell were in Charlottesville, Va., in August 2017 to cover the violent “Unite the Right” rally of white nationalists, or, as Ms. Owen called it, “a brazen display of hatred.”

headline: The Feelings Were There, Even When Words Were Not
text: Kobina Amani Johnson and Abrielle Kiana Moore had been talking for weeks by the time Mr. Johnson asked Ms. Moore for her phone number with the intention of inviting her on a date. But Mr. Johnson waited a week before sending his first text message to Ms. Moore at around 11 p.m. on a Saturday night in December 2017. At the advice of a friend who told him not to immediately suggest a get-together, he simply said, “hey.”

headline: Hitting a High Note on and Off the Opera Stage
text: Jordan Leigh Rutter and Vincent Joseph Covatto both say a certain magnetism drew each to the other at Heartbeat Opera’s annual Halloween drag gala in October 2016.

headline: A Two-Week Trip That Took Them Out of the Friend Zone
text: Jennifer Noinaj didn’t think she would ever get married, but after a year with Andrew Perry Chu, who goes by his middle name, she changed her mind.

headline: If at First You Don’t Succeed at Love, Try an Instagram DM
text: When Carly Lena Sophie Stein first saw Oliver Samuel Kremer’s profile on Hinge, she almost swiped left.

headline: No Longer Running From My Emotions
text: When I bumped into him on the street in Rome last summer, we hadn’t seen each other for nearly a decade. You know how people say that you’ll fall in love when you least expect it? I am never not expecting it. On every plane, at every coffee shop, I’m always hoping for a spark with someone.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Elizabeth II, Whose 7-Decade Reign Linked Generations, Dies at 96
text: “I don’t think people around the world realized just how brilliant she was. It’s like losing your grandmother. My wife will be in tears when I get home tonight.”

headline: Corrections: Sept. 9, 2022
text: An article on Thursday about the challenges the Department of Justice faces in its investigation into Donald J. Trump’s retention of highly classified documents at his home in Florida described incorrectly a judge’s order appointing a special master to examine documents taken from Mr. Trump’s residence. Her decision to allow the arbiter to review the files for any potentially shielded by executive privilege was in response to a request by Mr. Trump’s lawyers. It did not go beyond what they had argued.

headline: Frances Tiafoe vs. Carlos Alcaraz in the U.S. Open Men’s Semifinals: How to Watch
text: Those who have been worried about the state of men’s tennis when the likes of Roger Federer, Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal are retired have nothing to worry about.

headline: ‘We Deserve Gold Medals’
text: It was after 2 a.m. on Sept. 10, 1972, when Tom McMillen and Tom Burleson made their way to the Hofbräuhaus, the famed beer hall in central Munich, so they could commiserate in the dark over German sausage and pilsners.

headline: As Crises Mount, Europe Turns Once Again to Big Spending
text: BRUSSELS — Nationalizations. Subsidies. Cash handouts. Price caps. Profit taxes. It’s back to 20th-century economics in Europe.

headline: Magic Mountains: Novels of Appalachia From Natalie Lloyd and David Barclay Moore
text: The magic of flight — as depicted by creatures such as birds, butterflies and fireflies — is just one of the shared themes of two new middle grade novels, Natalie Lloyd’s “Hummingbird” and David Barclay Moore’s “Holler of the Fireflies.” Another is transformation, as experienced by the books’ protagonists, who choose to put themselves in challenging and unfamiliar circumstances that they must navigate in order to … if not exactly survive then evolve.

headline: Behind Josh Allen, Bills Take Rams in Hand
text: INGLEWOOD, Calif. — The N.F.L.’s season opener is always a hyped affair, but the Super Bowl-champion Los Angeles Rams’ game against the Buffalo Bills, a preseason favorite of football pundits, came down to a number of quieter dramas.

headline: After Long Brawl, South Carolina Senate Approves More Abortion Restrictions
text: The South Carolina Senate voted Thursday night to tighten abortion restrictions but failed to pass a total ban after a heated debate revealed the ongoing struggle among Republicans to define a cohesive post-Roe strategy.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: Queen Elizabeth II, Britain’s longest-serving monarch, died at 96 yesterday afternoon at Balmoral Castle in Scotland, her summer retreat. Members of the royal family rushed to be at her bedside. The family’s announcement did not specify a cause, but said she had “died peacefully.” Read our obituary.

headline: Rising energy prices amid a standoff with Russia over Ukraine are pushing Europe to spend big again.
text: BRUSSELS — With people across the European Union facing painful inflation driven by higher fuel costs, the bloc’s energy ministers plan to meet Friday to discuss how to remedy their distress.

headline: James Corden Pays Tribute to the Queen
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: succinct
text: The word succinct has appeared in 114 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 22 in “This Game Is Why the Word ‘Jaw-Dropping’ Exists” by Tania Ganguli:

headline: The U.S. and Russia clash at the U.N. over military aid.
text: At the United Nations Security Council on Thursday, sparring between Russia and the West centered on the supply of foreign weapons and military equipment to Ukraine on a day when the United States announced it would allocate an additional $675 million in military supplies.

headline: Charles addresses Britain on his first full day as monarch.
text: LONDON — King Charles III, in his first address to the nation as sovereign, made clear his intention to carry on his mother’s legacy while honoring her service, telling the nation in a televised speech, “Our values have remained and must remain constant.”

headline: Distance
text: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Queen Elizabeth II: The One Constant in an Inconstant World
text: She did not complain. She did not call in sick. She did not descend into self-pity. She did not deviate from tradition, at least not if she could help it. She did not show her emotions in public. When her beloved husband, Prince Philip, died during the dark days of Covid, she adhered to government guidelines by sitting apart from everyone else at his funeral, the picture of stiff-upper-lip stoicism and rectitude in black mourning clothes and two face masks.

headline: North Korea Adopts New Law Hardening Its Nuclear Doctrine
text: SEOUL — North Korea has adopted a new law that says the country will launch a nuclear attack if the United States or South Korea tries to remove its leader, Kim Jong-un, from power, state media reported on Friday.

headline: 5 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
text: This week's roundup includes titles by Lauren Groff, Louise Erdrich and more.

headline: Should More Parents Play Video Games With Their Kids?
text: Do you ever play video games with the grown-ups in your life? Or do they think video games are bad for kids?

headline: Traveling This Fall? Expect Cheaper Prices, ‘Seasonal Drift’ and, Yes, Chaos
text: After a haywire summer of flight cancellations and delays, travelers remain eager to roam, returning to familiar hot spots like New York, Europe and the Caribbean. Here’s what they can expect this season.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, September 9, 2022
text: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: As Wildfires Grow, Millions of Homes Are Being Built in Harm’s Way
text: The number of homes in fire-prone parts of the West soared from 10 million in 1990 to 16 million today, a big reason wildfires are causing more destruction.

headline: The Treasure America Scavenges From the Poor
text: I first sold plasma in 2009 after years of avoiding it. It was a temporary solution to a continuous state of financial instability.

headline: Ling Ma’s Surreal Subversions
text: In her 1993 book “A Woman’s View,” the film historian Jeanine Basinger observed a peculiar phenomenon in early Hollywood movies about women: They almost always included a sequence depicting “the protagonist in her marginal territory of joy.” Sound-tracked by a swelling score, the elegantly dressed leading lady would, in the company of a lover, throw her head back in laughter, beam over dinner, stroll contentedly in the park or dance into dawn.

headline: Elizabeth Bailey, Who Helped Deregulate Airlines, Dies at 83
text: In March 1979, on an Eastern Airlines flight to Tallahassee, Fla., from Atlanta, a flight attendant got into a disagreement with a late-boarding passenger who insisted that the airline was obligated to place her in a nonsmoking section, rather than in the back of the plane among the puffers. When the attendant welcomed passengers over the plane’s intercom several minutes later, she was still miffed.

headline: A Premature Victory Lap for Black Lives Matter
text: If racial progress in America tends to arrive in waves, much of it has come in the form of two crashing breakers: the First Reconstruction, which ended slavery after the Civil War, and the Second, which ended Jim Crow segregation a century later. The historian Peniel E. Joseph believes we have just witnessed a third such moment, bracketed by Barack Obama’s election in 2008 and the wake of George Floyd’s murder in 2020.

headline: I.R.S. to Refund Late-Filing Penalties for 2019 and 2020 Returns
text: About 1.6 million taxpayers who missed deadlines for filing their 2019 and 2020 federal income tax returns will get automatic refunds of late-filing penalties under a new Internal Revenue Service pandemic relief program.

headline: The Cost of Driving in Manhattan
text: This summer, after a near quarter-century of anxious procrastination, I got a driver’s license, a minor triumph followed by a commitment to getting in the car and traveling in increasingly longer increments. This mission in exposure therapy brought a personal best over Labor Day weekend. On a cloudless afternoon with little traffic, I drove my son to visit a friend in Duxbury, Mass., a trip of about 60 miles from our starting point in Rhode Island and one that, even though made under the least imaginably stressful conditions, still left me with the vague sense that I was undertaking a risk along the lines of going heli-skiing in Kashmir.

headline: The Plane’s a Filthy Mess. Who’s to Blame?
text: The camera pans across the floor below two rows of passenger seats. The carpet is littered with so many potato chip crumbs it appears as if there was a recent in-flight snowfall.

headline: Two Barbers, a YouTube Channel and the Truth About Race at the Racetrack
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Rasi Harper and Maurice Davis arrived in Louisville a couple of days before the Kentucky Derby in May, carrying their video cameras and searching, as always, for true stories of life at the racetrack.

headline: Biden Is Telling You That Trump Is a Threat, and the Proof Is Everywhere
text: President Biden is right. The so-called MAGA movement, led by Donald Trump, is a direct threat to democratic self-government in the United States.

headline: Downsizing in Retirement: Expenses They Didn’t Expect
text: Louise Angel Kiss and her husband, Charles, lived in their four-bedroom, split-level house in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue, Wash., for 40 years. Their two daughters had moved away long ago, and the couple decided they’d had enough of the stairs and the hassles and costs of upkeep. Like many older homeowners, they decided to downsize.

headline: Alex G and the Art of Interesting Choices
text: PHILADELPHIA — On a blustery Thursday in June, the 29-year-old musician Alex Giannascoli sat on a bench in tranquil Penn Treaty Park, overlooking the Delaware River, the breeze occasionally shaking loose acorns from an overhead tree. Giannascoli, who is known professionally as Alex G, has dark, shaggy hair and a disheveled handsomeness that makes him look a bit like a softer, more approachable Andrew W.K. He clutched a large Dunkin’ Donuts coffee cup and, whenever he felt like he’d gone on a tangent, blamed the caffeine.

headline: China’s Public Puts on a Show of Zero Covid for an Audience of One
text: As fire was raging in the mountains surrounding the southwestern Chinese metropolis of Chongqing, 10 million residents stood in 100-plus-degree heat to get Covid tests. Two cases were detected that day in August.

headline: What My Family and I Saw When We Were Trapped in China’s Heat Wave
text: SHANGHAI — Last month, I traveled with my wife and 5-year-old daughter from our home here to southwestern China for a family camping trip.

headline: How Silicon Chips Rule the World
text: When I first arrived in Taiwan as a college student in the summer of 1973, there was no ambiguity whatsoever about the American role on the island.

headline: To Grandmothers’ House We Go. Next Door.
text: In a city with no shortage of unusual real estate stories, Adele Geffen Eil and Judith Seligson have created one of the more unexpected living arrangements in New York.

headline: What This War Correspondent Wants You to Know About America and Fear
text: Luke Mogelson is a journalist for The New Yorker who has reported from some of the world’s most harrowing and unlucky places, including Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria and Liberia. Before he returned to the United States in 2020 to cover our political convulsions, he hadn’t spent more than a few consecutive months in his native country in almost a decade.

headline: 16 Easy Recipes for Hungry, Busy People
text: We’ve shaken the sand from our shoes and tucked away our swimsuits until next summer, and the busyness of fall has begun: The calendar is filling up with to-dos and appointments, and if you can believe it, holiday plans. The days can sometimes feel like they’re slipping by, but stopping to make a simple meal and enjoy it can help you slow down and smell the proverbial roses. These recipes are blessedly easy, the kind you can cook once or twice, then cook from memory. Put them together while chatting with your loved ones about their days or booking your plane tickets home for Thanksgiving.

headline: How Do Japanese Show They Care? By Sending a Telegram.
text: TOKYO — When he got married this summer, Hiroshi Kanno, who works at a security services firm in Tokyo, wanted to make a big statement that would impress his future in-laws.

headline: With Drought, ‘Spanish Stonehenge’ Emerges Once Again
text: Like the skeleton of an extinct sea monster, the Dolmen of Guadalperal has resurfaced from the depths of the Valdecañas reservoir in western Spain, where Europe’s persistent drought has caused water levels to plummet and submerged monuments to come to light. The remnants of this Bronze Age sepulcher, nicknamed the Spanish Stonehenge, are now fully exposed for only the fifth time since the area was deliberately flooded in 1963 as part of a rural development project.

headline: Gods of 125th Street
text: In 1976, Ricky “Slick Rick” Walters’s Jamaican British family moved from South London to the Bronx, where he would go on to become one of the most influential rappers of early New York hip-hop. But as he puts it in ICE COLD: A HIP-HOP JEWELRY HISTORY (Taschen, $100), “I’ve been telling stories through my attire and adornments for as long as I’ve been telling them with beats and rhymes.”

headline: Some Like It Not: Are Men in Dresses Still Funny?
text: Men in dresses are in vogue on Broadway. Just before the pandemic, there was “Tootsie,” and just after the shutdown, “Mrs. Doubtfire.” Now comes “Some Like It Hot,” a musical adaptation of the classic caper comedy about two men who dress as women to escape the mob.

headline: Bill de Blasio Knows New York Is Tired of Him. He’s at Peace With It.
text: For decades, as Bill de Blasio climbed the political ladder, he resolutely insisted he was a New Yorker. This insistence came even though he was raised primarily in Boston — well, nearby in Cambridge, technically — and kept his childhood fealty to the Red Sox.

headline: The Queen in New York, From a Ferryboat to Bloomingdale’s
text: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at Queen Elizabeth II and New York, a city she visited three times in her long reign. We’ll also hear former Mayor Bill de Blasio’s reflections on a subject he has had time to reflect on: former Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: A California County Braces for Fire, Floods and Mudslides, All at Once
text: Riverside County, already facing a growing wildfire, was placed under multiple extreme weather advisories on Friday as a tropical storm threatened to bring high winds, lightning, flooding and mudslides to the area in Southern California.

headline: How Queen Elizabeth II Preserved the Monarchy
text: The death of Queen Elizabeth II on Thursday brought to an end a remarkable reign that spanned seven decades, 15 prime ministers and 14 American presidents.

headline: Premier League Soccer Games Postponed After Queen’s Death
text: LEEDS, England — A swath of sporting events across Britain, including the entire professional soccer schedule, were canceled in the hours after the death of Queen Elizabeth II, with most likely to remain on hiatus through the weekend as a mark of respect.

headline: For Australians, Too, It’s the End of an Era
text: The death of Queen Elizabeth II, Britain’s longest-reigning monarch, has reverberated around the world. Amid the outpouring of grief on social media and in news coverage, her passing inevitably renewed questions about the monarchy’s role, including in Commonwealth countries, like Australia, where she was the head of state.

headline: Buckingham Palace provides details about tributes to the queen.
text: Buckingham Palace released details on Friday morning about protocol for floral tributes, the closing of royal residences and a period of mourning to mark the death of Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: An Era Ends
text: She became queen when Britain was only seven years removed from World War II, and she went on to have the longest recorded reign of any monarch in world history other than Louis XIV.

headline: Austrian Takes Over as Top U.N. Human Rights Official
text: GENEVA — A week after Michelle Bachelet stepped down as the United Nations’ high commissioner for human rights, the U.N. has approved Volker Türk, an Austrian who is a trusted adviser to the secretary general, to take on the notoriously challenging job.

headline: Thousands of Angry Indonesians Gather to Protest Rising Fuel Prices
text: JAKARTA — Thousands of protesters rallied across Indonesia this week calling for the government to reverse its first price hike on subsidized fuel in eight years, and vowing to continue demonstrations until President Joko Widodo meets their demands.

headline: 2 Years After Deadly Fistfights, India and China Pull Back From Border
text: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — Their soldiers have fought with fists, rocks and wooden clubs along a disputed frontier high in the Himalayas. Both India and China have said they don’t want a war, but the brawls led them to move thousands of soldiers to inhospitable terrain.

headline: The queen’s death draws a more muted response in India, the largest of Britain’s former colonies.
text: In India, the government declared a day of mourning on Sunday, with flags flying at half-staff to honor the late Queen Elizabeth II. But her death provoked a muted reaction across much of the country, the largest in the Commonwealth of Nations, an association of mostly former British colonies.

headline: Remember ‘Avatar’? Neither Do We. Catch Up Before the Sequel Arrives.
text: What can be accomplished in 13 years? Given that much time, J.K. Rowling published all seven of the Harry Potter books — and helped turn the first six of them into movies. Taylor Swift cranked out eight studio albums — and rerecorded two of them. The Yankees won the World Series eight times.

headline: Navalny, a jailed Putin critic, says Russia has revoked his attorney-client privilege.
text: Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed Russian opposition leader, said on Thursday that the prison authorities had deprived him of his attorney-client privilege, which has been his main line of communication with the outside world and has allowed him to remain active in Russian political life.

headline: Dissecting the Royal Family’s Wealth
text: Yesterday, Britain mourned the death of Queen Elizabeth II and welcomed the ascension of her son as King Charles III. Much attention will be paid to the formal procedures of royal mourning and the crowning of a new monarch — but it’s also worth examining the state of a multibillion-dollar fortune that will change hands as well.

headline: Artists discuss how they turned the queen into an icon.
text: LONDON — When Chris Levine, a Canadian artist, was commissioned to make a holographic portrait of Queen Elizabeth II, who died in Scotland on Thursday, he took an unusual approach to getting her to relax.

headline: How Readers Are Reducing Their Carbon Footprint
text: Thirty years ago, the temperature in Los Angeles typically reached 90 degrees 56 days a year. By 2072, climate models suggest there could be 87 days annually when the temperature hits that mark.

headline: Harry leaves Balmoral Castle, with uncertain plans ahead.
text: Prince Harry was seen leaving Balmoral Castle in Scotland on Friday morning, having spent the night there after the death of his grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: ‘The Rings of Power’ Season 1, Episode 3: Island Time
text: The audience reactions to last week’s “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power” premiere ran the gamut from a warm reception to the show’s expensive-looking special effects and old-fashioned adventure-fantasy sprawl to a dispiriting campaign of social media bile, aimed in part at the diverse casting and the balance of male and female heroes. What is especially vexing about the race- and gender-focused gripes is that the story this series is telling — similar to the one J.R.R. Tolkien told in his books — is largely concerned with how different groups overcome their biases and superstitions for a higher cause. In other words: The various ways these multihued creatures look and act is kind of the point.

headline: U.S. Open Semifinals: The 4 Men Left
text: Men’s tennis will have a first-time Grand Slam winner by Sunday: Frances Tiafoe, Carlos Alcaraz, Karen Khachanov or Casper Ruud.

headline: In a Power Crisis, South Africans Adjust to Life in the Dark
text: Blackouts are no longer merely a problem in South Africa. They have become a crisis that affects nearly every facet of life.

headline: Amid Crypto Downturn, Two Big Names Cut Deal
text: The venture arm of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, helmed by the billionaire investor Sam Bankman-Fried, announced on Friday that it had taken a 30 percent stake in SkyBridge Capital, the hedge fund founded by Anthony Scaramucci, for an undisclosed sum. SkyBridge will use $40 million from the proceeds to buy cryptocurrencies to strengthen its long-term balance sheet.

headline: Siddhartha Mukherjee Weaves History and Biology to Tell the Story of Us
text: Books, Siddhartha Mukherjee says, just tumble out of him, like fluffy towels and clean socks cascade out of a dryer at the end of the cycle. And it’s a good thing, because it’s not as if the man has a lot of idle time to spare.

headline: ‘Three Divas, What Could Be Better?’ Making ‘The Hours’ Operatic
text: New York City’s opera event of the fall — an adaptation of “The Hours” having its staged premiere at the Metropolitan Opera in November — started with a pitch from Renée Fleming.

headline: Did You Recently Buy an Electric Vehicle? We Want to Hear About It.
text: People are buying electric vehicles at a record pace, snapping up battery-powered cars and trucks as quickly as automakers can make them. In just a few years, electric vehicles have gone from expensive novelties for the superrich to a must-have product for many people.

headline: Issy Wood Met Power Players in Art and Music. She Went Her Own Way.
text: For the last three years, through art fairs, auctions, a global pandemic and an album release, the British painter and musician Issy Wood has been perfecting the craft of being pursued professionally.

headline: The Weekender
text: Inside New York’s private pools. Also in this edition: Christine Baranski’s throwback flair, and an interview with the soccer star Kylian Mbappé.

headline: S.E.C. Chair Doubles Down on the Need to Regulate Cryptocurrencies
text: The chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Gary Gensler, has repeatedly warned that cryptocurrencies must be regulated to protect investors. On Thursday he took a big step toward that goal, saying he will work with Congress to help create legislation that would increase crypto oversight.

headline: What You Get for $5 Million in California
text: A 2017 residence near Manhattan Beach Pier, a rustic beach house in Bolinas and a four-bedroom condominium in an Edwardian building in San Francisco.

headline: The Burn Test
text: My summer break is over. This summer of flames is not.

headline: Claw Clips Claw Their Way Back
text: Bethany Simko didn’t mean for claw clips to become her TikTok claim to fame. If it weren’t for one forgetful moment earlier this summer, they might never have been.

headline: A Back-to-School Book List for the Ages
text: There is a unique and palpable energy around back-to-school season. For some, it’s the beginning of something brand-new and unexplored; for others, it’s a time for reinvention and much anticipated milestones. No matter what the emotions surrounding a new school year, one thing is for sure: No kid is alone in how he or she is feeling.

headline: Camilla Becomes Queen Consort, Capping Years of Image Restoration
text: LONDON — Earlier this year, Queen Elizabeth issued a letter that was seen as a major moment of recognition for a long beleaguered member of the royal family, intended to smooth the path for her ascent when the inevitable finally came.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
text: Good morning. You miss me? Here’s what I did on my summer vacation: made a lot of pizzas, 63 percent hydration in my dough. Took a lot of long walks through browned and crusty fields. Caught striped bass in the foaming rips between boulders on the shoreline. Read some terrific fiction — Rebecca Rukeyser, Ling Ma, Sebastian Barry. Drove great distances. Ate very well.

headline: How Well Do You Know These Novels Set in California?
text: America’s Golden State has long been a place for storytelling in many forms. Can you name the California locations where these books take place?

headline: Kurt Gottfried, Physicist and Foe of Nuclear Weapons, Dies at 93
text: Kurt Gottfried, a theoretical physicist who barely escaped the brutal reality of one world war and devoted his career to preventing another as a co-founder of the influential Union of Concerned Scientists, died on Aug. 25 in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: Was Biden’s Democracy Speech Too Harsh?
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Africa, the queen’s death renews a debate about the legacy of the British Empire.
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Though Queen Elizabeth II was revered by many in Africa, her death also reignited a different sort of conversation — one that touched on the legacy of the British Empire and the brutality the monarchy meted out to people in its former colonies.

headline: How Ivo van Hove Turns a Novel Into a Play
text: We followed the theater director in and around Amsterdam and through rehearsals as he developed a new work, adapted from a book by Édouard Louis.

headline: Hate Doing the Dishes? Try These 3 One-Pot, One-Pan Recipes.
text: There’s nothing that makes me appreciate the streamlined ease of a one-pan meal more than watching a professional chef at work.

headline: Arsenic in N.Y.C. Water Sample Came From a Testing Error, Lab Says
text: Days after New York City officials said they had found potentially dangerous levels of arsenic in the tap water at a Manhattan public housing development, they delivered a stunning turnabout on Friday, saying arsenic had been added to the sample during a laboratory test and there had never been elevated levels in the water.

headline: Björk Insists on Connection, and 11 More New Songs
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Los Angeles County Investigates Death of Person With Monkeypox
text: Los Angeles County officials said this week that they were investigating the death of a person who had been diagnosed with monkeypox to see if the illness was a contributing cause of death.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
text: This sprawling and incisive action thriller from the Indian director Anubhav Sinha offers a distinctive glimpse into the divergent political and cultural identities found in India’s northeast.

headline: A Filmmaker Explores David Bowie’s Life and Finds Clarity About His Own
text: When the documentary filmmaker Brett Morgen hit his eighth month of writer’s block on an epic project about David Bowie, he decided it was time to hit the road. With just a few hours’ notice, he left his home in Los Angeles one morning and grabbed the first flight to Albuquerque, where Bowie had filmed “The Man Who Fell to Earth” (1976). When Morgen arrived, he took a cab to the train station and hopped aboard an Amtrak, heading west.

headline: Trump Media Gets Aggressive With Regulators Over Delayed Merger
text: The upstart social media company backed by former President Donald J. Trump appears to be taking a more aggressive approach with regulators as it seeks approval for its delayed merger with a cash-rich shell company.

headline: What will happen to the queen’s royal pack of corgis?
text: Among the many transitions that Queen Elizabeth II’s death has set in motion for Britain will be one that affects the smallest, and perhaps cutest, members of the royal family: the monarch’s pack of four royal dogs. These include two corgis, a corgi-dachshund cross (known as a dorgi) and a cocker spaniel.

headline: King Charles III is formally proclaimed to his new role.
text: Two days after the death of Queen Elizabeth II, her son Charles’s new role as British monarch was officially proclaimed on Saturday in a ceremony at St. James’s Palace in London.

headline: In London, Mourning, Remembrance and Tributes. And Some Shrugs.
text: LONDON — Gertrude Dudley remembers sitting on her grandfather’s shoulders in 1953 at the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, a monarch she came to know as “the fabric of Britain.”

headline: He Stole Another Man’s Name to Rejoin the Army. He Got Caught Decades Later.
text: Joel Sanders served in the United States Army from 1985 to 1988. Originally from St. Louis, Mr. Sanders was stationed in Berlin, and after being medically discharged, he stayed in Germany and made a life for himself, having six children and founding a security business.

headline: Joseph Hazelwood, Captain of the Exxon Valdez, Is Dead at 75
text: Joseph Hazelwood, the captain of the tanker Exxon Valdez, which ran aground on a reef in the icy waters of Alaska’s Prince William Sound in March 1989, dumping at least 10.8 million gallons of crude oil in one of America’s worst environmental disasters, has died. He was 75.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
text: After a summer full of breaks, the late-night hosts returned just in time to talk about the documents the F.B.I. found at Mar-a-Lago. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: Balmoral, a Cherished Royal Getaway in Scotland, Becomes a Place of Pilgrimage
text: BALMORAL CASTLE, Scotland — By 7:30 on Wednesday morning, the flowers already lined the walls outside Balmoral Castle, the beautiful and remote Scottish country estate much loved by Queen Elizabeth II, and where her life and seven-decade reign ended on Thursday.

headline: This Fish Has a Smart Shortcut
text: Hello, everyone. I missed writing to you when I was out on my summer vacation, though I didn't miss trying to come up with different ways to say “delicious.” (“Toothsome!”)

headline: Wonking Out: The Mysteries of the Almighty Dollar
text: In 1971, John Connally, Richard Nixon’s Treasury secretary, told his counterparts from other major economies that “the dollar is our currency, but it’s your problem.” The context — the lingering demise of the Bretton Woods currency system — is ancient history. But his statement, remarkably, still rings true after all these years.

headline: Mr. Mayor, Who Are You Wearing?
text: The mayor of New York City is not a labels guy.

headline: Queen Elizabeth, and the Power and Limitations of Inspiring Women
text: LONDON — There is a certain story about women’s progress that goes something like this: For too long, women have been held back by the personal prejudices of misguided individuals, and by society’s failure to imagine their potential for dazzling achievement. But if one extraordinary woman could cut her way through, proving the doubters wrong, others would be able to follow in her footsteps. And if women can lead, equality will follow.

headline: ‘American Gigolo’ Review: Can You Take the Escort Out of the ’80s?
text: Whatever else you thought of Paul Schrader’s 1980 Southern California noir, “American Gigolo,” you couldn’t deny that it nailed its post-disco, pre-Reagan moment: the blurry, enervated style, like a music video on quaaludes; the tragic-young-man story of a high-class hooker brought low by his hubris and refusal to play by the rules; the clinical fascination with the luxury goods he used to armor himself. (And the casting of those ultimate luxury goods Richard Gere and Lauren Hutton.)

headline: When Crisis Is a Constant
text: Chelsea managed to cycle through it all in nine hours, give or take. First, bright and early on Wednesday, came the announcement that the club’s owners had decided to dispense with the services of Manager Thomas Tuchel, after a reign encompassing a mere 19 months and one measly Champions League title.

headline: Tina Ramirez, Founder of a Leading Hispanic Dance Troupe, Dies at 92
text: Her company, Ballet Hispánico, performed for audiences across the United States and beyond. It also trained countless dancers.

headline: Hochul Declares Polio State of Emergency for New York
text: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York declared a state of emergency on Friday over the growing polio outbreak, in an effort to better equip health care providers with tools to curb the spread of the sometimes disabling virus before it takes further hold in the state.

headline: M.L.B. Bans the Shift and Adds a Pitch Clock for 2023
text: Radical defensive shifts are headed the way of flannel uniforms, train travel and organ music as Major League Baseball, a sport searching for its identity, moved Friday to institute some significant rules changes for 2023.

headline: Here is the transcript of King Charles III’s inaugural address.
text: King Charles III delivered his first address as sovereign Friday, after the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II. The following is a transcript of his remarks, as released by the palace.

headline: Love Letter: Yes, I’m Intense
text: “For a long time, I focused on what the intensity of my emotions has taken from me. But my feelings also have given me the ability to imagine vivid possibilities.”

headline: Buy American? It Gets Complicated.
text: For all their differences, President Joe Biden resembles former President Donald Trump in one way: Both are huge believers in the “Buy American” cause. Just five days after his inauguration, Biden issued an executive order toughening requirements for the federal government to purchase from domestic sources where possible. A White House document said this would “ensure that our future is made in all of America by all of America’s workers.”

headline: The U.S. Must Invest in the People Who Care for Children’s Mental Health
text: My stomach lurched when I answered the phone at my therapy practice. On the line was the latest worried and exasperated parent hoping to schedule a psychotherapy appointment with me for a child or teenager. I’m one of the few child and adolescent therapists in my area, and I dreaded telling this mother that my schedule is full. I listened to her, provided a couple of referrals and suggested some self-help or online resources the family can use while they wait for a therapy opening with someone else.

headline: Inside Trondheim, One of Europe’s Northernmost Creative Hubs
text: Welcome to T Wanderlust, a new travel newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Twice a month, we’ll recommend global destinations and hotels worth visiting. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every other Friday, along with our T List newsletter each Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: B.Y.U. Says It Found No Evidence of Racial Slurs at Volleyball Match
text: Brigham Young University said Friday that it had completed its investigation into accusations of racial heckling and slurs at a volleyball match against Duke University last month and found no evidence to confirm that the behavior took place.

headline: A Great Podcast, a Worthy Memoir and a Curdled Take on Clarence Thomas
text: I spent the summer away from New York City and this week am back into the swing of my real life. Already, I’ve been gobsmacked by things relating to the three topics I cover here the most.

headline: In New Hampshire, a MAGA Rivalry Is Splitting House Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — He calls her “fake MAGA Karoline” from “the swamp.” She calls him a “Fauci foot soldier” and a “pharma bro.”

headline: In Ohio, Biden Says Democrats Have Started a Manufacturing Revival
text: WASHINGTON — President Biden attended the groundbreaking for a $20 billion computer chip factory on Friday in a heavily Republican part of Ohio, testing the power of his election-year message that Democrats have helped start a manufacturing revival with record amounts of government spending.

headline: Galileo Forgery’s Trail Leads to Web of Mistresses and Manuscripts
text: When the University of Michigan Library announced last month that one of its most prized possessions, a manuscript said to have been written by Galileo around 1610, was in fact a 20th-century fake, it brought renewed attention to the checkered, colorful career of the man named as the likely culprit: Tobia Nicotra, a notorious forger from Milan.

headline: Credit Card Sales at Gun Stores Would Be Flagged Under New Code
text: An organization that sets standards for business transactions has voted to create a special code for gun stores to use when processing credit and debit card transactions, a move long sought by gun safety advocates who say it will help law enforcement officials spot suspicious purchases.

headline: Why King Charles’s profile may face left on British coins, and why it matters.
text: There are 29 billion British coins in circulation with Queen Elizabeth II’s face on them. Since she first appeared on the coins, a year after her ascension in 1952, the Royal Mint has used five different portraits. And on all of them, she faces to the right.

headline: Biden Administration Outlines Scope of Asian Economic Pact
text: The Biden administration on Friday concluded its first round of in-person negotiations for a proposed trade pact with more than a dozen Asian nations, the initial steps toward an agreement that officials said would reassert American influence in the Pacific and counter China’s dominance of the region.

headline: The Royal Grief You Will Not See
text: Death holds up a mirror to everything — moments of love, stretches of strife, memories that punish and exalt. This is true if your family is far removed from the public eye, and it’s true if your family is ensconced in the world’s spotlight.

headline: Thomas Carney, Crusty Bartender at Elaine’s, Dies at 82
text: Thomas Carney, who served stiff drinks, hard-boiled humor and rough justice for three decades as the bartender in chief of Elaine’s, a saloon that furnished an improbable gathering place for New York’s writers, actors, athletes, models, power brokers, journalists, police officers, gangsters, playboys, go-getters and countless wannabes, died on Aug. 30 at his home in Palm City, Fla. He was 82.

headline: Charles, in First Speech as King, Pledges a Reign of Service to Britain
text: LONDON — Swiftly taking on the mantle of Britain’s monarch, King Charles III returned to London from Scotland on Friday, a day after the death of Queen Elizabeth II, to pledge that he would serve the British people “with loyalty, respect and love, as I have throughout my life.”

headline: Queen Elizabeth II Understood the Weight of the Crown
text: She died in her happy place. It was a photograph of herself and Prince Philip at Balmoral, wrapped in a tartan picnic blanket beside the hills of her beloved Loch Muick, that she chose to release on the eve of his funeral last year. Balmoral is where it is said he proposed to her and where, throughout her life, she spent contented summer months unassailed, except by her own family.

headline: Ukraine Claims Major Gains in Kharkiv
text: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: ‘Burbank’ Review: When Disney’s Animators Went on Strike
text: On the lawn outside Walt Disney’s snazzy new animation studio in Burbank, Calif., a young woman is out cold. The apple that was going to be her meager lunch has slipped from her grasp and rolled away.

headline: Russia Holds First Elections Since Ukraine Invasion, but Opposition Is Mostly Absent
text: MOSCOW — Russians began voting on Friday in the first nationwide elections since the invasion of Ukraine in a climate of wartime censorship and repression, with the Kremlin trying to assure the public that it was business as usual.

headline: People Are Weight Training Barefoot. Is There Any Upside?
text: About two years ago, Claire Haeuptle, a physical therapist based in San Diego, was interested in strengthening the muscles and ligaments of her feet. Dr. Haeuptle, who played four years of collegiate basketball, has a history of knee injuries, including five surgeries.

headline: William and Catherine are now Prince and Princess of Wales.
text: The titles King Charles III granted Friday upon his oldest son, William, and William’s wife, Catherine, bridged two distinct eras of the royal family.

headline: Ukraine Attacks Russia Along Northern Front, Swiftly Making Gains
text: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainian forces have scored the most significant battlefield gains since they routed Russia from the area around Kyiv in April by reclaiming territory in the northeast, according to Ukrainian officials, Western analysts and battlefield imagery.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Lars Vogt, Acclaimed Pianist and Conductor, Is Dead at 51
text: Lars Vogt, a sensitive, communicative pianist whose warmth as a collaborator made him an outstanding chamber musician and a conductor of growing stature, died on Monday at a clinic in Erlangen, Germany. He was 51.

headline: Sheila Tobias, Who Defined ‘Math Anxiety,’ Dies at 86
text: When Sheila Tobias finished her freshman year at Radcliffe College in 1954, her professor in a natural sciences course congratulated her on her performance. But for many years she was troubled that he had not encouraged her to take more science classes. When she finally asked him, he said that her limited science background had already made her ineligible for a science career.

headline: The American Guided Rockets Helping Ukraine Destroy Russian Forces
text: Out of the billions of dollars in weapons the White House has shipped to Ukraine since the Russian invasion, perhaps none have attracted as much attention as the M142 HIMARS, an advanced rocket launcher that Ukrainian troops have used to devastating effect.
